issue.title: Use gometalinter installer for all golang syntax checkers
issue.body:
Most of the go linters are installed using gometalinter which keeps a versioned copy of the dependencies.
However we still have the manual install of
go get -u sourcegraph.com/sqs/goreturns
go get -u github.com/BurntSushi/toml/cmd/tomlv

tomlv isnt a linter of go language, so it wont be suitable for gometalinter, but it is less likely to break with go versions because it doesnt check go syntax which changes with each golang version and doesnt depend on golang syntax parsers which improves (aka breaks) with each golang version.
goreturns could be  proposed to gometalinter, allowing us to maintain all go syntax linters via gometalinter
(See #2599 for removal of unnecessary go gets)

issue.title: JSONBear: New setting to expand layout of sub-objects up to a certain level
JSONFormatBear: Message not appropriate when settings are omitted
issue.body:
This file can be reformatted by sorting keys and following indentation.

is always displayed, regardless whether you have actually enabled json_sort (to sort keys) or not. Especially it's displayed when you omit the setting altogether, and the default is actually false. So you think that the default is true.
The message has to be flexible for different parameters, so a user won't become confused.
Acceptance criteria:

The JSONFormatBear produces following messages for results in case that reformatting is possible:

When json_sort is False, the result message should be just This file can be reformatted by following indentation..
When json_sort is True, the result message should be like before (This file can be reformatted by sorting keys and following indentation.)

issue.title: Add NakedretBear
issue.body:
Implement a new linter bear that wraps https://github.com/alexkohler/nakedret
nakedret checks for functions whether they use so called "naked returns" in go, when they exceed a specified length. If a function is very long, naked returns hinder readability and maintenance. They should be avoided in such cases.

issue.title: Enhance coala-html and integrate into coala core
issue.body:
https://github.com/coala/coala-html is a nice project, but it is an angular application which limits its user scenario and popularity. Users have to install and run an angular application to see the results. What we could possibly do is to make use of coala-html, enhance it and integrate it with coala core. Maybe as a coala CLI option, e.g. '--generate_report'. When using that option, static web pages will be generated.
https://github.com/pyta-uoft/pyta is a project initiated by the University of Toronto. It looks like a minified version of coala, but is designed to be beginner-friendly. After running the tool, it does not generate reports via CLI, but via static web pages. The attached zip file is a sample report generated by pyta.
PyTA Error Report.html.zip

issue.title: Project Proposal: Improvements and Enhancements in coala community & projects website
issue.body:
Project Proposal
Improvements and Enhancements in community website
Enhancements


Gamification Leaderboard

Addition of a new column named issues that will show all the labels of issues that user has solved.
Addition of a Search bar where a user can search any username in case there is a long record displayed on the page and a filter option can also be provided where the user wants to view a set of records according to his needs.
If possible, we can add a new column in leaderboard which will display the total time taken by the user to solve all the issues that were assigned to him.
Instead of displaying activities on the leaderboard page we can show these activities on the profile page (to be created) as it will save space on the leaderboard page and we can accumulate more data and columns.
Filtering of records between GCI participants and NON-GCI participants.
(Thinking on) Changing static website to dynamic website because the records of users are not static they change with time as they gain new skills, solve new issues, no more a GCI participant as they are have grown up etc.



Homepage

We can show up a leaderboard that shows up top 10 contributors of the current month(a drop-down having options with the weekly, monthly or yearly view) and NON-GCI and GCI participants will have a separate leaderboard, will have a drop-down option.



Add Login/Sign-up using GitHub


Create Profile Page

Requirements: User should be logged in using GitHub
Display all user related information and stats like it's rank, issues solved by that user, graph, contribution details and many more.



User

If possible, we can store the contribution details of users i.e. how much a user has contributed to which repository/community more and we can display that data on the graph or in some other format.
In Leaderboard, we can set username a hyperlink which will link to a profile page of the user(to be created).



Improvements


Gamification Leaderboard

Display all rendered results in a table format because currently the results are shown in a paragraph format
To make it more creative, we can show some medals/badge emojis based on data in badges columns and show these emoji beside the username.



UI

Re-designing of the website and making it responsive so that it looks good on different devices.
In Inactive Issue and unassigned issues activity web pages, instead of showing just JSON they should be displayed in proper format with some extra important information.
Contributors and Meta-Review data web pages should be redesignedto make it look good.



Improvements and Enhancements in projects website
Enhancements

In reference to project proposal #394

Currently, the website shows all projects together (Completed, Disabled and Open projects). Instead of showing them together we can group this projects so that user can easily navigate to any section.
A new section can be added that can show the count of grouped projects(e.g. their x open projects, y disabled projects and z completed projects).
Also, IMO we can show stats of projects like how many new projects proposals were accepted out which how many were completed and compare it with previous years data. (Thinking more on it if it can be more enhanced).
Since coala provides a linter for the code so we can provide information on how a particular completed project will benefit other orgs. And how they can use them in there code maintenance.
PENDING: Requirement analysis of other GSoC and GCI Orgs.



Improvements

UI

Add UI to reports page that lists all previous year GSOC project.
Improve UI of user reports page.
The responsive view looks to ugly need to be improved and materialize.css should be replaced by bootstrap.
Language drop-down at the bottom of the page doesn't seem to be working so either it should be removed or add some functionality to implement that language changer of the page.



Extension to GSoC 2018 project with  new additions and in reference to project proposal.

issue.title: Travis is failing on master due to andrewda/trav
issue.body:
Travis has been failing on master for days, the latest failure is: https://travis-ci.org/coala/community/builds/459360893
Running .ci/build.sh locally leads to the same error:
python manage.py distill-local public --force
OH_TOKEN can not be obtained: 'Please put your OH API key at .OH_API_KEY.'
CommandError: Failed to render view:

which is not a very useful message (see mgrp/django-distill#10 also)
I used git bisect and found out the first problematic commit was 98031ce, which introduced https://github.com/andrewda/trav as a dependency. Build succeeds when that commit is dropped.
Very likely, some updates on https://github.com/andrewda/trav lead to the Travis failure.
ping @andrewda

issue.title: Add OpenHub for each org
issue.body:
Use URL guessing to detect whether an org exists in OpenHub , and add a link for any which was found.
PRs do not have access to an OpenHub token, so can not use one.  However we can add an OpenHub token to do extra detection which will run on the master builds after merge.
The majority of GCI orgs have one ( http://openhub.net/orgs/ ).

https://www.openhub.net/orgs/JBoss
https://www.openhub.net/orgs/Wikimedia
https://www.openhub.net/orgs/coala
https://www.openhub.net/orgs/Wikimedia
https://www.openhub.net/orgs/openmrs
https://www.openhub.net/orgs/639 (Sugar Labs..)
https://www.openhub.net/orgs/fedora
https://www.openhub.net/orgs/haiku
https://www.openhub.net/orgs/MetaBrainz
https://www.openhub.net/orgs/OSGeo
https://www.openhub.net/orgs/236 (Drupal, really)
https://www.openhub.net/orgs/kde

Success for this task requires correctly linking to 2/3 of those found above.

comments.bodyText: @soumya-ranjan7 @li-boxuan Review this please

@li-boxuan
I checked locally by adding JSONFormatBear on two sections and checked the appropriate message displayed when the json_sort value is either true or false.
Then I moved on to writing test using LocalBearTestHelper.
I was using check_results for the test cases.
But I got a assertion error like this,
AssertionError: {'default': <coalib.results.Diff.Diff object at 0x7f7aec04acf8>} != {'default': <coalib.results.Diff.Diff object at 0x7f7aec05f9e8>}
This error is created by the check_results function inside LocalBearTestHelper.py .
It's comapring this whole string. But It should be comparing the Diff object's attribute values. This will always be false since the memory location will be always different.
In our codebase, the places where check_results is used was always used if the Diff object is None.
But here we are checking the message when the Diff is not None.
This type of test case is not tested previously. And check_results doesn't seem appropriate for this.
So what should I do in this case ?
Updated:
Approaches we can proceed with:
Creating a custom string reprsentation of diff object will resolve this.
Or defining a object.__eq__(self, other) function in coali.results.Diff would also work.

@naveentvelu check_results should work. Compare the strings from both of the Result objects yourself. (See the length difference, assert wherever required to find out the difference between the two). You  should be able to get your mistake, if not then post the entire pytest error on gitter.

@abhishalya
The check_results will not work because, we have a diff object which is not None. So when you compare two of them their ids get compared rather than their attributes.
If you see the above assertion error,
It is because of diffs(one of the attributes of 'result' class) which belongs to <class 'dict'>. This has a key-value pair filename : <class 'coalib.results.Diff.Diff'>.
In the current implementation of check_results, this key-value pair is directly being compared.This causes the assertion error.

See the length difference, assert wherever required to find out the difference between the two.

This is not needed here because there will always be mismatch in the id's of class objects even if they have the same attribute with same values.

@abhishalya @li-boxuan
Finally one of the approaches work, I added a def__repr__(self): function in Diff class. And It solved the above assertion error.
Should I create a issue along with PR for modifying the Diff class?
It's in coala/coala repo. https://github.com/coala/coala/blob/master/coalib/results/Diff.py

Then I moved on to writing test using LocalBearTestHelper.
I was using check_results for the test cases.
But I got a assertion error like this ...

Post your code snippet, or just push with your unfinished code, so that people have a better understanding of your problem or find bugs with your code if there is any.

Then I moved on to writing test using LocalBearTestHelper.
I was using check_results for the test cases.
But I got a assertion error like this ...

Post your code snippet, or just push with your unfinished code, so that people have a better understanding of your problem or find bugs with your code if there is an

I got it right now. The mistake was on my side. I passed the wrong expected diff value. Sorry @li-boxuan @abhishalya

issue.title: Fix CommitBear coverage drop
issue.body:
Fix coverage drop by rolling back nltk to 3.3
Fixes #2788
nltk 3.4 was  released on the 17th. The coverage drop happened with #2786 which was merged on Nov 17th. On my machine, using nltk 3.3 brings back coverage for 70 -> exit.
Line 70 is setting a lambda for logger, which would be passed to redirect_stdout. On the subsequent lines, nltk is called. Perhaps there are some changes in nltk 3.4 that broke this.
I spent a couple of hours looking at the tests and couldn't find anything else that could have caused the coverage drop. I believe this is the likely culprit.

comments.bodyText:
Sorry if my review wasn't very clear. Take pyre_bad.py:2 for example.
    return 'string'
pyre says the error happens on line 2, column 4.
Now the problem comes:
What is column 4? Is the first column numbered 0 or 1?
Back to our example. It is clear that there are 4 spaces before return. Very likely, they consider the position of the first character of return, as the error position, i.e. the position of r. They call this position column 4. If that is the case, we can infer that they count column numbers from 0. However, coala counts from 1. column 4 needs to be converted into column 5 in coala.
But I am not sure. I don't know how they come up with column 4. Maybe they are referring to the last space before the word return, but chances are small. Maybe they have inconsistencies/bugs within their tool. You need to look up in their documentation (or even code), or ask them in their community.
It might not be an easy task, but such 'tiny' thing is important. coala needs to be accurate: sometimes upstream linters are not accurate, and we detect problems and help solve them.
Let me know if my words are not clear enough 😉

forseeable future, I would like my name removed from
all projects, so people don't contact me about them.

comments.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,10 @@
+---
+question: "What is a cEP and why it is so important to do analysis pre-gsoc and design as early as possible, to be finalized in the cEP?"
+---
+A **cEP(coala Enhancement Proposal)** is a proposal proposed to the coala community discussing the new major features that the contributor is intended to implement during GSoC.
+
+**cEP's** are designed before implementation. Implementing major features usually happens from a technical perspective and may lead to not well-designed content - developer and user wise. This can essentially save a lot of coding work when big features are written which are oftentimes not well enough designed initially. This also makes sure that major features are properly documented.

comments.bodyText:
IMO that line should be there

I disagree. Everyone applying for gsoc know the possible outcome of either getting selected or rejected. The way @KVGarg has mentioned it would make us seem like a community that is too hard to get into which is far from what this community is actually like. I have not seen a community where the maintainers and the admin try so hard to select every good student for GSoC and even advise them to submit multiple proposals to other organizations.
So I am with @utkarsh2102 on this. It should be rephrased like an interested student must do enough research about their project to be able to express their ideas, timeline, etc clearly in their GSoC proposal which will increase their chances of success.
What you ( @KVGarg  ) wrote is absolutely correct but I just don't find it very welcoming towards newcomers.

issue.title: nested-languages.md: Update the Proposal
issue.body:
The proposal is updated for handling nested
language which is one of the Gsoc projects
to understand the concept of handling nested
language more better.
Closes #547

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

issue.title: backends.py: Add profile_link function
issue.body:
This function is created to map github and gitlab usernames.
Ensures correct profile links are mapped for both websites.
Fixes #347
Reviewers Checklist

 Appropriate logging is done.
 Appropriate error responses.
 Handle every possible exception.
 Make sure there is a docstring in the command functions. Hint: Lookout for
botcmd and re_botcmd decorators.
 See that 100% coverage is there.
 See to it that mocking is not done where it is not necessary.

comments.bodyText: @sladyn98 The changes you made I think are only valid for gitter as backend. You need to find the ways of mapping usernames for other backends too. Also, you need to use this function while creating the issue.

@abhishalya but I think the issue description mentions issues created only via gitter right?In terms of  other backends we would by default have to just make a guess for the username because we won't be absolutely sure that they are the original gitlab/github usernames.

issue.title: .coafile: Update .coafile to new format
issue.body:
Closes #148

For short term contributors: we understand that getting your commits well
defined like we require is a hard task and takes some learning. If you
look to help without wanting to contribute long term there's no need
for you to learn this. Just drop us a message and we'll take care of brushing
up your stuff for merge!
Checklist

 I read the commit guidelines and I've followed
them.
 I ran coala over my code locally. (All commits have to pass
individually. It is not sufficient to have "fixup commits" on your PR,
our bot will still report the issues for the previous commit.) You will
likely receive a lot of bot comments and build failures if coala does not
pass on every single commit!

After you submit your pull request, DO NOT click the 'Update Branch' button.
When asked for a rebase, consult coala.io/rebase
instead.
